definition: **noun / hi-fi accessory.** A **dedicated stand or floating platform that decouples a turntable from floor-borne vibration** — often uses sorbothane feet, springs, or constrained-layer shelves. Emerged in the 1970s as audiophiles recognized that footfalls, speaker feedback, and structural resonance could reach the stylus and degrade sound quality. Early solutions included sand-filled plinths and DIY concrete slabs; by the 1980s, commercial platforms using elastomer isolation, pneumatic bladders, or mass-loaded constrained-layer damping became standard in high-end systems. Modern designs range from simple sorbothane pucks ($20-50) to engineering-grade platforms with tuned spring arrays and magnetic levitation ($500-3,000). Particularly critical for suspended-subchassis turntables and installations near speakers or on upper floors. Effectiveness measured by resonance frequency reduction—quality platforms isolate below 3Hz. Audiophile debates persist over material choice: some prefer inert mass (granite, butcher block), others favor active damping. Wall-mounted shelves offer superior isolation by bypassing floor coupling entirely. Essential for extracting maximum fidelity from high-resolution cartridges where microphonic interference becomes audible.
etymology: Compound term combining 'turntable' with 'isolation platform' from engineering vibration control terminology; adopted by hi-fi industry in mid-1970s as audiophile awareness of mechanical feedback grew.
